This section of tissue is naturally supported by the cardinal ligament that goes laterally to the ischial spine and crosses over medially to the sacrospinous ligament, and also by the uterosacral ligament that anchors into the sacrum. Level 2 support of vaginal tissue is support of tissue of the mid section of the vagina, below the bladder. This tissue is partially supported by the cardinal ligament but is predominantly supported by lateral fascial attachments to the arcus tendineus or white line. Level 3 support is that of the front end (sometimes referred to as the "distal" section) of the vagina right under the urethra. Natural support includes lateral fascial attachments that anchor into the obturator internus muscle.

The method for inserting the implant for treating vaginal prolapse can include providing an implant that includes a tissue support portion and two or more extension portions; placing the tissue support portion in contact with vaginal tissue to support the vaginal tissue; and extending a posterior extension portion to engage a sacrospinous ligament, and extending a lateral extension portion to engage tissue at a region of ischial spine, or extending a posterior extension portion to engage a sacrospinous ligament, and extending an anterior extension portion to engage an obturator foramen, or extending an extension portion to engage a sacrospinous ligament to provide Level 1 support, and supporting vaginal tissue to provide Level 2 support. Figure 16 of US-2010-0261955-A1 illustrates a kit with an implant having a support portion piece, two extension portion pieces, adjusting tool, grommet management tool, and insertion tool.
In some modes of practice, the implants of the invention can be used along with an expansion member in a sacral colpopexy is a procedure for providing vaginal vault suspension, such as described in commonly assigned International Application No. PCT US 11/53985. A sacral colpopexy generally involves suspension, such as by use of a mesh strip implant, of the vaginal cuff to a region of sacral anatomy such as the sacrum (bone itself), a nearby sacrospinous ligament, uterosacral ligament, or anterior longitudinal ligament at the sacral promontory. The implant can be utilized in a transvaginal sacral colpopexy (TSCP) procedure with an expansion member to access tissue of the posterior pelvic region.

claim.claim-text: 1. A medical implant configured for placement at a pelvic location and release of a therapeutic agent, the implant comprising a multilayered film comprising three or more therapeutic agent-containing layers and two or more intermediate regulating layers that are different than the therapeutic agent-containing layers and that modulate release of the therapeutic agent from the film, each intermediate layer positioned between two therapeutic agent-containing layers.

2. The medical implant of claim 1 wherein the three or more therapeutic agent-containing layers comprise two outer therapeutic agent-containing layers and one internal therapeutic agent-containing layer, the internal therapeutic agent-containing layer positioned between the intermediate regulating layers.
3. The medical implant of claim 2 wherein the therapeutic agent-containing layers and the regulating layers are absorbable.

4. The medical implant of claim 3 wherein the outer therapeutic agent-containing layers comprise an absorbable polymeric material having a rate of degradation that is faster than the rate of degradation of the absorbable polymeric materials in the internal therapeutic agent-containing layer and intermediate regulating layers.
5. The medical implant of claim 3 wherein the outer therapeutic agent-containing layers comprise an aliphatic polyester copolymer, such as PLGA, or a polyorthoester.
6. The medical implant of claim 3 wherein the internal therapeutic agent-containing layer and the intermediate regulating layers comprise an aliphatic polyester homopolymer, such as PLLA or PCL.

7. The medical implant of claim 2 wherein the outer therapeutic agent-containing layers are absorbable, the internal therapeutic agent-containing layer is partially absorbable, and the regulating layers are non-absorbable, or partially absorbable.

8. The medical implant of claim 7 wherein the regulating layers comprise a polymeric material selected from crosslinked hydrophilic polymers, such as crosslinked poly(vinyl pyrrolidone), poly((meth)acrylamide), poly(urethane), hyaluronic acid, alginate, dextran, starch, amylopectin, cellulose, xanthan, pullulan, chitosan, pectin, inulin, and heparin.

9. The medical implant of claim 7 wherein the regulating layers comprise pores having a size of 3 μιη or greater, such as in the range of about 3 to about 50 μΜ, about 5 to about 50 uM, about 5 to about 40 μΜ, about 5 to about 30 μΜ, or about 5 to about 25 uM.

10. The medical implant of claim 7 wherein the internal therapeutic agent-containing layer comprise an absorbable polymeric material, and islands of hydrophilic polymer which adhere to the regulating layers.

11. The medical implant of any of the previous claims wherein the outer therapeutic agent-containing layers comprise a steroid, such as estradiol, estriol, or estrone, or an antibiotic, such as doxycycline, tetracycline, minocycline, azithromycin.

12. The medical implant of any of the previous claims wherein the inner therapeutic agent-containing layer comprise a steroid, such as estradiol, estriol, or estrone, or an antibiotic, such as doxycycline, tetracycline, minocycline, azithromycin, or a growth factor such as transforming growth factor beta (TGF-beta), platelet derived growth factor (PDGF), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

13. The medical implant of any of the previous claims wherein any of the therapeutic agent-containing layers, or regulating layers have a thickness in the range of about 0.5 um to 25 μπι, or about 1 μηι to 10 μιη.

14. A medical implant configured for placement at a pelvic location and release of a therapeutic agent, the implant comprising a woven or non-woven mesh comprising a plurality of apertures, wherein a portion of the apertures comprise a membrane comprising a therapeutic agent, and each aperture comprising a membrane is adjacent to at least one open aperture.
15. The medical implant of claim 14 wherein the sizes of the apertures in the mesh are in the range of about 0.2 mm2 to about 2 mm2, or in the range of about 0.5 mm2 to about 1.5 mm2.
16. The medical implant of claim 14 wherein a photosensitive compound is used to form the membranes in the mesh.
17. The medical implant of claim 14 wherein the portion of the apertures filled with membrane is the range of about 10% to about 60%, about 20% to about 50%, or about 25% to about 45%.

18. The medical implant of any of claims 13-17 wherein the membrane comprises an erodible polymeric material selected from polyhydroxyalkanoates such as poly-4- hydroxybutyrate (P4HB), poly(3-hydroxyvalerate, and poly(hydroxybutyrate-co- hydroxyvalerate); polyesters such as polylactic acid, poly(lactide-co-glycolide), polycaprolactone, poly(valerolactone), poly(glycolic acid), poly(glycolide), and poly(dioxanone); polyorthoesters; polyalkerieanhydrides such as, poly(sebacic acid); polyanhydrides; polyphosphazines

19. The medical implant of any of claims 13-17 wherein the therapeutic agent comprises a steroid, such as estradiol, estriol, or estrone, or an antibiotic, such as doxycycline, tetracycline, minocycline, azithromycin, or a growth factor such as transforming growth factor beta (TGF-beta), platelet derived growth factor (PDGF), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

20. A medical implant configured for placement at a pelvic location and release of a therapeutic agent, the implant comprising a strip or sheet comprising a plurality of pores that comprise one or a combination of therapeutic agent(s), wherein:
(a) the plurality of pores comprises pores having different volumes, where following implantation, to provide a prolonged therapeutic agent release profile; or

(b) wherein a portion of the plurality of pores are covered with a bioabsorbable material, where following implantation, the bioabsorbable material is degraded to uncover the pores to provide a prolonged therapeutic agent release profile.
21. The medical implant of claim 20 wherein each pore has a volume in the range of about 5000 μιη3 to of about 0.1 mm3, or about 50000 μηι3 to of about 0.01 mm3.
22. The medical implant of claim 20 wherein the strip or sheet has a thickness in the range of about 0.1 mm about 1.45 mm, or about 0.25 mm to about 0.72 mm.
23. The medical implant of claim 20 wherein the strip or sheet has a total pore volume in the range about 0.1 mm3 to about 10 mm3.
24. The medical implant of claim 20 where, in (b) a portion of the pores are covered with a bioabsorbable material layer that is an aliphatic polyester copolymer, such as PLGA, or a polyorthoester.
25. The medical implant of claim 24 where in (b), a first portion of the pores are covered with a first polymeric layer, and a second polymeric layer partially covers the first polymeric layer.

26. The medical implant of claim 25 wherein the first polymeric layer comprises an aliphatic polyester homopolymer, such as PLLA or PCL, and the second polymeric layer comprises an aliphatic polyester copolymer, such as PLGA, or a polyorthoester.
27. The medical implant of claim 20 where in (b), first polymeric layer, the second polymeric layer, or both, have a thickness in the range of about 0.5 μτη to 25 μτα, or about 1 μπι ΐο 10 um.

28. The medical implant of any of preceding claims comprising a support portion configured for the support of an anatomical structure in the pelvis selected from the group consisting of the vagina, bladder, urethra, or levator ani.
29. The medical implant of any of preceding claims comprising as straps or arms that extend from a support portion of the implant.
30. The medical implant of any of preceding claims comprising tissue anchors or fasteners such as self-fixating tips for maintaining the implant at a desired anatomical location in the pelvis.
31. The medical implant of any of preceding claims configured for treating incontinence in a subject.
32. The medical implant of any of preceding claims configured for treating urinary incontinence in a female subject.
33. The medical implant of any of preceding claims configured for treating vaginal prolapse, including anterior prolapse, posterior prolapse, and vault prolapse.

34. A kit comprising the medical implant of any of preceding claims optionally including components for carrying out procedures for the insertion of the implant in a patient, the optional components comprising tissue fasteners, implantation tools for introducing the implant into a patient using a surgical insertion procedure, scalpels or knives for making the incision, and needles and suture material for closing the incision.
34. A method for treating incontinence using the implants or kits of any of the preceding claims.
35. A method for treating vaginal prolapse using the implants or kits of any of the preceding claims.
